children.name: the feeling you have when you are hungry
hunger
children.definition: the feeling you have when you have eaten very little food: cơn đói
examples: The baby screamed with hunger.
Many slimming diets don’t provide enough calories to satisfy hunger.

children.name: hunger pangsthe uncomfortable feelings in your stomach that tell you are very hungry: đau bụng đói
examples: If you do feel hunger pangs, nibble on carrot, celery, or cucumber sticks.

children.name: appetite
children.definition: the feeling of wanting to eat when you have not eaten for some time - use this especially when sb does not have their normal desire to eat, for example when they are ill: sự thèm ăn
examples: How’s his appetite? Is he getting enough to eat?
Her husband always had a huge appetite.
Symptoms include tiredness and loss of appetite.

children.name: a good/healthy appetite
examples: Growing children should have a healthy appetite.

children.name: a big/huge/enormous appetite
examples: By the time Ron was 16 he had an enormous appetite.

children.name: a poor appetite
examples: A poor appetite may be a sign of illness.

children.name: a small appetite
examples: My aunt only had a small appetite.

children.name: have an appetite
examples: There’s lots of food – I hope you have a good appetite.

children.name: lose your appetite
examples: She was so miserable that she completely lost her appetite.

children.name: give sb an appetite
children.definition: alsostimulate your appetiteformal
examples: The exercise and fresh air had given us an appetite.|The aroma of the herbs and spices helps stimulate the appetite.

children.name: spoil/ruin your appetite
children.definition: make you not feel like eating a meal
examples: Don’t give the children any more sweets – it will spoil their appetite.

children.name: loss/lack of appetite
examples: Symptoms include fever and loss of appetite.|I’m a bit worried about her lack of appetite.

children.name: need a drink
children.definition: especially spoken to want to drink sth, especially because you are very thirsty or because you want an alcoholic drink:cần uống gì đó
examples: Jeez it’s hot. I need a drink.
I need another drink if we’re going to keep talking about this.

children.name: dry
children.definition: when yourthroatormouthis dry, it has very little liquid in it, so that you feel that you want a drink:khô
examples: My throat was so dry I could hardly speak.

children.name: dehydrated
children.definition: sb who is dehydrated, does not have enough liquid in their body and feels weak and ill:mất nước
examples: When exercising, especially in the heat, drink often or you will become dehydrated.

children.name: severely dehydrated
examples: Children who have diarrhoea can quickly become severely dehydrated.

children.name: thirsty
children.definition: khát
examples: Are you thirsty? Do you want some juice?
On a hot day, your dog can become very thirsty, so make sure they have plenty of water.
By the time you actually feel thirsty, your body is already slightly dehydrated.
Stands were set up to satisfy the thousands of thirsty people expected at the event.

children.name: thirstyworkUK an activity that makes you thirsty, used especially humorously when you want an alcoholic drink
examples: I’ll have a beer. Gardening is thirsty work, you know.

children.name: hungry
children.definition: đói
examples: By four o'clock Ifelt/ wasreally hungry.
We were really hungry after our long walk.
Are you hungry? Do you want a sandwich?
Hungry shoppers waited in line at the food counters.

children.name: peckish
children.definition: /ˈpekɪʃ/  UKinformala little hungry:đói
examples: The kids were getting peckish so Sammy found a cafe nearby.
I’m feeling a bit peckish. What’s in the fridge?
By ten o'clock I was feeling rather peckish, even though I'd had a large breakfast.

children.name: feel like sth to eat
children.definition: spokento want to eat sth:muốn cái gì đó để ăn
examples: It’s 12 o'clock - do you feel like something to eat?
Do you guys want something to eat?

children.name: have the munchies
children.definition: have/ get the munchiesinformalto begin to feel a little hungry, and want sth to eat, especially sth small rather than a large meal:có chút đói, có vẻ đói
examples: If you get the munchies later on there are some cookies in the kitchen.
I've gotthe munchies.

children.name: when people are ill or dying because they do not have enough to eat
famine
children.definition: a situation in which a large number of people in a country or area are very hungry and many die because the crops of rice, wheat etc have failed: nạn đói kém
examples: Millions of people in Africa continue to die because of war and famine.
The four-year drought has caused widespread famine across Afghanistan.

children.name: severe/ widespread famine
examples: Widespread famine had triggered a number of violent protests.
A million people arefacing famine.

children.name: starvation
children.definition: suffering or death caused by not having enough food to eat: sự chết đói, sự đói khát
examples: The survivors were close to starvation when they were rescued.
A global fall in the price of rice spread hardship and even starvation to many parts of Indochina.

children.name: die of starvation
examples: 30 million people die of starvation each year.

children.name: brink of starvationalmost dying because of not having enough food gần như chết đói
examples: Thousands of refugees are on the brink of starvation in camps south of the capital.

children.name: hunger
children.definition: Many people could die from cold and  this winter as the war continues.
examples: The slum-dwellers suffer from poverty, hunger, and disease.
All over the world, peopledie ofhunger every day.

children.name: weak with/ from hunger
examples: Weak with hunger, she staggered up to the cabin door.

children.name: not be hungry
children.definition: không đói

children.name: ‘How about something to eat?’ ‘No thanks, I’m not hungry.’
examples: We offered her some sandwiches but she said she wasn’t hungry.

children.name: lose your appetite
children.definition: to no longer want to eat anything, especially because you areupsetorillorthinkingabout sth else:không thấy đói
examples: Jane’s not feeling too well and has lost her appetite.
I shifted the food around my plate, suddenly losing my appetite as he told me the news.

children.name: not feel like anything
children.definition: not feel like/not want anythingspokeninformalsay this to tell someone that you are not hungry:không cảm thấy, muốn ăn gì cả
examples: I had a really big lunch, so I don’t feel like anything just now.

children.name: ‘Do you want some toast?’ ‘No thanks, I don’t want anything.’
get hungry
children.definition: to start to feel hungry, especially because you have not eaten for some time: đói bụng
examples: Is it lunchtime yet? I’m getting hungry.
If youget hungry, there’s some cold chicken in the fridge.

children.name: work up an appetite
children.definition: to do sth to make yourself want to eat, especially by hard physical exercise:làm gì đó cho đói bụng
examples: After a long day walking across the hills they had worked up quite an appetite.
There’s nothing like skiing to work up an appetite.

children.name: give sb an appetite
children.definition: if work, exercise, etc gives you an appetite it makes you feel hungry:khiến cho đói bụng
examples: All that exercise has given me an appetite.
Spending all day in the fresh air had given them all an appetite.

children.name: starving
children.definition: sb who is starving has not had enough food for a long time and will die soon if they do not eat: đói khát
examples: The people are starving and they need all the food and medical supplies we can give them.
They have barely enough money to keep them from starving.
a country full of starving people
the starvingpeople who are starving những người đói
The homeless and the starving, refugees of the war, were flocking to the cities.

children.name: starve
children.definition: to have so little food to eat that you become ill or die: đói khát
examples: The prisoners were taken out into the desert and left to starve.
In 1884, the crew of Young’s ship nearly starved when they were blown off course.

children.name: starve to deathstarve and die chết đói
examples: Unless these people get food in the next two weeks they will starve to death.

children.name: hungry
children.definition: if people are hungry, they need food but do not have enough food to eat over a long period of time:bị bỏ đói
examples: My children are hungry, I need a job.
Hungry people crowded around the relief wagon for food.

children.name: go hungrynot get food to eat đói
examples: If the crops fail again this year thousands of people will go hungry.
Thousands of families go hungry every day.
She oftengoeshungry herself (= does not eat) so that her children can have enough to eat.

children.name: not get enough to eat
children.definition: to not be given enough food, so that you are becoming ill: thiếu ăn
examples: The refugees in the camps are not getting enough to eat, and the living conditions are terrible.
A baby who is not gaining weight is probably not getting enough to eat.

children.name: half-starved
children.definition: thin and looking ill because you do not have enough to eat:đói khát
examples: Poor dog! He looks half-starved.
The soldiers were dirty and half-starved.

children.name: underfed
children.definition: written people or animals who are underfed are not being given enough food to eat:thiếu ăn, bị bỏ đói
examples: The servants were overworked and underfed.

children.name: I could eat a horse
children.definition: !spokenhumorous used to say that you are very hungry :
examples: ‘Are you hungry?’ ‘Yeah, I could eat a horse.’

children.name: starving
children.definition: / ravenous/starvedUS  spoken very hungry:đói chết được, đói cồn cào
examples: Can we talk about this after dinner, please? I’m famished.
I missed lunch and I’m starved.
Normally she did not eat a lot in the morning, but today she was ravenous.

children.name: absolutely starving/ ravenous
examples: I’ve been driving for eight hours non-stop and I am absolutely starving.

children.name: famished
children.definition: very hungry.Famishedis less common and sounds a little more formal thanstarvingorravenous:
examples: Everyone was famished by the time they arrived.

children.name: the feeling you have when you are thirsty
thirst
children.definition: the feeling of wanting to drink sth:cơn khát
examples: The soldiers suffered constantly from hunger and thirst.
Maggie woke up with araging thirst(= an extremely strong thirst ).

children.name: quench your thirstget rid of your thirst by drinking somethinglàm hết khát
examples: After a workout, juices are excellent because they quench your thirst and replace fluids and carbohydrates.

children.name: die of thirstdied from a lack of sth to drinkchết khát
examples: Seven people died of thirst after their truck broke down on an isolated desert road.

children.name: work up a thirstdo work or exercise that makes you thirsty
examples: The bars and cafes cater to tourists who have worked up a thirst sightseeing.

children.name: be dying for
children.definition: /be gasping forUK spokento want to drink sth very much:muốn uống cạn
examples: We were dying for a Coke, so we stopped at a fast-food place.
I’m gasping for a cup of tea.

children.name: be dying for a drinkto want to drink sth, especially alcohol
examples: I’m dying for a drink. Want to go for a pint?

children.name: parched
children.definition: informal if sb is parched they are very thirsty. You can also say that they have a parched throat or parched lips when they are very dry and they need a drink:khát khô cổ họng
examples: She put her water bottle to his parched lips.
Give me a sip of that I’m parched.
They were dirty and parched, but in remarkably good condition after the rescue.

children.name: on an empty stomach
children.definition: without eating anything
examples: _You shouldn't go to work on an empty stomach.

children.name: make sb's mouth water
children.definition: makesb'smouth water làmaithèm chảy nước dãi

children.name: If the smell or sight of food makes your mouth water, it makes you want to eat it
examples: _The smell of that bacon cooking is making my mouth water.

children.name: smack your lips
children.definition: smackyourlips

children.name: to close and open your mouth loudly to express a strong wish to eat something you like a lot
examples: _"I adore chocolate cake, " said Susannah, smacking her lips.
